The Univer&ity for Foreigners actually started to function in 1921 but it was formally
established by state law in 1925, That law said the purpose of the university was "to
spread abroad the knowledge of Italy in all its manifestations, past and present."
The academic year at the University for Foreigners consists of three terms of three
months each, and runs from April to December. There are three different sections _ for
beginning, intermediate and advanced students. Courses include the study of the language,
civil history, art history, philosophy, literature, and one devoted entirely to Dante's
"Divine Comedy."
In the 33 years of its existence, the University for Foreigners has enrolled some
17,000 students from 78 different nations.
The biggest single group of students has come from Germany, with Americans second.
But the annual invasion of American Fulbright grantees for their month of special orienta¬
tion is closing the gap.
That American invasion this year came on Sunday, September 26. Most of the Fulbright
granttes arrived in Naples aboard the SS Independence about noon on Saturday, September 25,
After clearing customs, they olimbed into buses and were taken up the Appian Way to Rome
for the night, stopping en route for dinner at a seaside restaurant near Formia. They were
up for an early departure from Rome on Sunday morning, andtheir buses slowly climbed the
zig-zagging highway from the upper Tiber valley to the crest of XS Perugia about noon.
After a group luncheon at a hotel just off the Corso, the Fulbrighters scattered to
the various Peruginian homes where they were to live for the next month. The next day,
Monday, the vacations ended; the orientation program began.
Miss Ida Haubold is an attractive redhead from Brooklyn, U. S. A. She studied fine
arts and painting at Hew York's Cooper Union and will study this academic year at the
Institute of Fine Arts in Florence.
Just 48 hours off the boat at Naples, Miss Haubold finds herself in a classroom at the
University for Foreigners, getting the drilling of her life in down-to-earth Italian from
a tall, handsome man with a Roman nose; friendly but very persistent,
